head.title: Description of the Country around Lakes Superior and Huron, 1809. - Page #19

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #19 of 97 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Johnston, John. Description of the Country around Lakes Superior and Huron, 1809. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0018

div.p: which are of considerable extent[.] If to this is added, the nature and inclination of the Rocks, which is either Basalt, or Freestone, the former of which bears evident marks of fusion, appearing often like Hills of melted metal which had cooled by degrees as it gained the water, The latter ever appearing more abrupt as if the adhering matter had been from them torn by convulsion from[.] It would appear that all this Country had undergon[e] many changes from Volcanic eruption, and internal commotion[.] Shortly after you leave the Second Recess you perceive a Cave the mouth of which is finely Arched and Slanting Longitudinally towards the Bay[.] I have never had time nor inclination to explore it, nor have I ever heard of any who had[.] The Point you have now to double Shoots out with great asperity the height cannot be less than 200 feet[.] On the top are several large Stones and Some nodding trees which equally threaten destruction; the mould being torn from about them by frost and Storms, they appear as If ready to detach themselves on the Slightest motion, and in fact hardly a Spring passes but some of them do come down as Soon as the thaw takes place[.] The Base of this Point is curious from the manner in which it is perforated which resembles bowls turned down and Others Set upon their bottoms the interstices giving you the idea of Porches and Gothic Windows, the water Rushing in and Regorging from them in a manner that by no means invites to close

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
